questions.text: Subepidermal bullae on trunk and flexural surface with linear C3/IgG basement membrane deposits are features of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bullous pemphigoid Sub epidermal blisters are seen in bullous pemphigoid, linear IgA disease and dermatitis herpetiformis. In the present question, IgG and C3 would be seen in bullous pemphigoid

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Pemphigus vulgaris will have epidermal blisters and IgG fishnet deposits Option C- Linear IgA disease will have IgA deposits linearly along the DEJ. Option D- dermatitis herpetiformis will have IgA deposits at the tip of dermal papilla in a granular pattern

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came to the emergency with a painful, erosive, crusted skin rash in his armpits. He said the rash increases with sweating. Histopathological examination of the rash showed a “Dilapidated brick wall” appearance. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hailey Hailey disease Hailey Hailey disease, or Benign familial Pemphigus, is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to defect in ATP2C1 gene mutation. Site of lesion: Neck, axillae, inframammary, groin, perineum ( at sites of friction) Characteristics of the rash: Flaccid vesicles with macerated plaques crusted weeping erosions, vesiculopustular and vegetative plaques. Nail finding: Longitudinal leukonychia Histopathology : Suprabasal acantholysis, Dyskeratosis, Despite extensive acantholysis, few intact intercellular bridges that still holds the keratinocytes together loosely given the appearance of dilapidated brick wall appearance

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Grover’s disease: Transient acantholytic dermatosis is an acquired itchy truncated rash characterized by acantholysis that occurs mostly in Caucasian men of 50 years of age. Option B. Darier’s disease: Begins in adolescence; it is an autosomal dominant hereditary acantholytic dermatosis. There are greasy, scaly papules often in Seborrhoeic areas. Histopathology shows a suprabasal cleft of the epidermis. Option D.Bowen's disease: It is Intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

Extraedge:

Disease Chromosome Gene Hailey hailey 3 ATP2C1 Darier disease 12 ATP2A2

questions.text: In which among the following Bullous disease, is subepidermal bullae not seen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pemphigus foliaceus Pemphigus foliaceus is a blistering disorder which shows intraepidermal or subcorneal bullae due to separation at the level of stratum granulosum Subepidermal blistering diseases are seen in Bullous pemphigoid Dermatitis herpetiformis Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita Mucous membrane pemphigoid Porphyria Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica Junctional Epidermolysis bullosa

questions.text: A patient with blistering disease presented to OPD. Investigation revealed autoantibodies against desmoglein-1. Which among the following can not be a differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bullous pemphigoid Bullous pemphigoid shows antibodies to BPAg 2 or BPAg 1 in the dermo-epidermal junction Pathogenic autoantibodies to desmoglein 1 are found in Pemphigus foliaceus, Mucocutaneous pemphigus vulgaris, and Paraneoplastic pemphigus. Infectious disorders -bullous impetigo and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented to OPD with greasy, scaly papules on his face, scalp and chest. Histopathological examination revealed corp grains and corp ronds. Which of the following is not true regarding the disease?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an autosomal recessive condition

options.label: B
options.text: It is caused due to dysfunction of SERCA2b protein

options.label: C
options.text: “v” shaped nicking of nails is seen

questions.correct_answer: A. It is an autosomal recessive condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is an autosomal recessive condition The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Darier disease. -Darier-White disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Pathology : A defective calcium pump of the sarcoplasmic/endoplasmic reticulum (SERCA2b) causes Darier’s disease. Clinical feature: It presents with Greasy, warty, keratotic papules in a Seborrhoeic distribution. Nails: Alternate leukonychia and erythronychia, V-shaped nick at the free end of nail Oral cavity: Cobblestone appearance Palms: Pitted lesion Histopathology : Corps ronds and grains are seen. Treatment: Systemic retinoids

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B.,C.,D: All are true.

Extraedge:

Disease Chromosome Gene Hailey Hailey 3 ATP2C1 Darier disease 12 ATP2A2

questions.text: A primo-gravida in her third trimester presented with intense pruritus and erythematous, urticarial papules and plaques in the periumbilical region. After a thorough examination, a diagnosis of herpes gestationis was made. Which of the following is not true regarding the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraepidermal blistering disorder Pemphigoid gestationis or herpes gestationis is a rare autoimmune bullous disorder with subepidermal split. It presents in late pregnancy( second or third trimester ) or immediate postpartum period . Autoantibodies directed against BPAg2 leading to blister formation. Features: Intense pruritus that occasionally precedes skin lesions. Erythematous urticarial papules and plaques typically involve the periumbilical region. Fetal prognosis is good, but there is an increase in the frequency of premature and small-for-date babies. It can recur in subsequent pregnancies No mucosal involvement Histopathological findings: subepidermal blister with eosinophils and lymphocytes DIF: Linear C3 deposition along the dermo-epidermal junction in 100% of cases and additional IgG in 30% of cases. Treatment: Mild disease: Topical and systemic steroids and emollients Severe disease: immunosuppressive drugs, IVIg and plasma exchange

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A.,B.,D. : All are true.

Extraedge:

Common bullous disorders and their target antigen Disease Target Antigen Pemphigus F oliaceous DSG-1 (mnemonic- F- First = 1) Pemphigus Vulgaris DSG-3> DSG1 Paraneoplastic pemphigus DSG1 Bullous pemphigoid BPAG1, BPAG2 Pemphigoid gestationis BPAG 2 Dermatitis herpetiformis Epidermal transglutaminase 3

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of generalised itching and multiple blisters over the body for 2 months. On Examination, multiple tense blisters over an erythematous base are seen on the back, abdomen, groin and extremities. Nikolsky’s sign is negative. Oral mucosa is normal. Clinical and DIF Image is attached. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bullous pemphigoid The given clinical scenario with Multiple tense blisters and negative Nikolsky sign is suggestive of Bullous pemphigoid . Bullous pemphigoid is an immunobullous disease that typically occurs in patients older than 60 years of age . Target protein: Hemidesmosome Target antigen: BPAG1, BPAG2 Characteristic of the lesion: large, tense blisters arising on normal skin or an erythematous or urticarial base. Site : flexural surfaces , the lower abdomen, and the thigh. Oral lesions in 10 to 30% of cases. Nikolsky and Asboe-Hansen signs are negative. Histopathology : subepidermal blister with predominantly eosinophilic and neutrophilic infiltrate. DIF : shows deposits of linear IgG and C3 along the basement membrane.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: Characterized by painful flaccid blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, most commonly inside the mouth. Positive Nikolsky sign and burka spread sign. Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: Chronic, intensely pruritic, subepidermal immunobullous disease associated with Gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Option D. Pemphigus Foliaceus: presents as superficial epidermal fragile bullae, which often present as erosions. The epidermis separates at the level of stratum spinosum due to defects in the desmosomal proteins. Mucosa is not involved.

Extraedge:

Common bullous disorders and their target antigen Disease Target Antigen Pemphigus F oliaceous DSG-1 (mnemonic- F- First = 1) Pemphigus Vulgaris DSG-3> DSG1 Paraneoplastic pemphigus DSG1 Bullous pemphigoid BPAG1(BP230), BPAG2(BP180) Pemphigoid gestationis BPAG 2 Dermatitis herpetiformis Epidermal transglutaminase 3

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with oral erosions and multiple blisters over the chest and abdomen for 3 months. The lesions initially started in the oral cavity and later ruptured to leave erosions. Later fluid-filled blisters were seen over the chest and abdomen. On examination, multiple erosions and ulcers in the buccal mucosa and a few flaccid and tense bullae were seen over the chest and abdomen. Identify the sign which is shown below concerning the history given
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nikolsky’s sign The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris and the sign shown here is Nikolsky’s sign Nikolsky sign: The sign is demonstrated when lateral shearing pressure is applied on the border of an intact blister, which results in the dislodgment of the normal epidermis and extension of the blister.

Highyeild:

Common causes of positive Nikolsky sign: Pemphigus Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome Stevens-Johnson syndrome/ toxic epidermal necrolysis Epidermolysis bullosa

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Sign of Leser-Trélat : a sudden eruption of multiple seborrheic keratoses caused by an internal malignancy. Option C.Darier sign : When Dermographism is limited to the skin overlying a lesion (macule or papule): Diagnostic of Urticaria pigmentosa (mast cell disease) Option D.Pseudo Darier's sign : Transient piloerection seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma.

questions.text: In the salt split technique, autoantibodies are detected in the floor of the blister in which condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita The split skin method is a simple and reliable method ( Modified indirect immunofluorescence) for distinguishing between the epidermal‐ and dermal‐binding autoantibodies . This method relies on splitting skin through the lamina lucida whereby Bullous pemphigoid and pemphigoid gestationis antigens adhere to the epidermal side and components of the lamina densa (laminin 332) Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita antigens (type VII collagen and type IV collagen )adhere to the dermal side i.e floor of blister

questions.text: A 40 year female came to the OPD with lesions on areas of the scalp, face, chest and upper back and small flaccid blisters which rupture easily can be appreciated easy.No mucosal lesions are seen . It shows intercellular staining showing a fishnet pattern. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pemphigus foliaceus Pemphigus foliaceus is an immunobullous disorder which is characterized by fragile, flaccid bullae that rupture to form scales/ crusted lesions. Target antigen: DSG1 Onset and site: Insidious, involving Seborrhoeic areas ( scalp, face, chest and upper back). Mucosa is not involved. Blistering may not be obvious because the cleavage is superficial, and the small flaccid blisters rupture easily.

Highyeild:

Direct immunofluorescence findings in common bullous disorders table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} Pemphigus Vulgaris Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of C3 with a reticular pattern Pemphigus Foliaceous Fishnet appearance Bullous pemphigoid Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction in bullous pemphigoid Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction zone, with a u-serrated pattern

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: Tense bullae present, usually above 60 years of age. Lesions are common on the flexural surface. Option C. Pemphigus Vulgaris: Also shows fishnet appearance on DIF but Mucosal involvement present and flaccid blisters are seen Option D. Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita: It is characterized by skin fragility, erosions, blisters, crusts and scarring over trauma prone areas. Scarring, alopecia and nail loss can occur.

questions.text: A female patient with multiple bullous erosions, which are flaccid on the body and also severe stomatitis came to the OPD physician is suspecting neoplasm in her what could be the possible association except for
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastric cancer The given clinical scenario with bullous erosions and malignancy suggests Paraneoplastic pemphigus. Paraneoplastic pemphigus is characterized clinically by severe stomatitis, conjunctivitis which may be scarring and oesophageal, genital mucosal and flexural involvement, and bullous and erosive lesions elsewhere. Cutaneous lesions may be erosive or blistering as in PV, though tense pemphigoid‐like blisters may occur, as well as erythema multiforme or lichenoid changes. IF changes : Features of both pemphigus and pemphigoid reflecting the broad spectrum of circulating anti-epithelial antibodies.

Highyeild:

Neoplasms associated with Paraneoplastic Pemphigus: Exclusively of hematological origin. Non‐Hodgkin lymphoma Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia Castleman disease, Thymoma Waldenström macroglobulinemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma: Paraneoplastic pemphigus (PNP) is most commonly associated with hematologic malignancies, particularly B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphomas. Option B. Thymoma : It is a rare neoplasm of the thymus gland that is often associated with autoimmune diseases, including PNP. Option C. Castleman disease: It is a lymphoproliferative disorder that can be associated with PNP.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male came to the OPD with pruritic blisters over his skin on examination they had a red base. The Nikolsky sign was negative. The antigen responsible for the same is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BP – 230 The given clinical scenario with Multiple tense blisters and negative Nikolsky sign suggests Bullous pemphigoid . Bullous pemphigoid is an immunobullous disease that typically occurs in patients older than 60 . Target protein: Hemidesmosome Target antigen: BPAG1(BP230), BPAG2(180) Characteristic of the lesion: large, tense blisters arising on normal skin or an erythematous or urticarial base. Site : flexural surfaces , the lower abdomen, and the thigh. Oral lesions in 10 to 30% of cases. Nikolsky and Asboe-Hansen signs are negative. Histopathology : subepidermal blister with predominantly eosinophilic and neutrophilic infiltrate. DIF : shows deposits of linear IgG and C3 along the basement membrane.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . DSG 3: This is the target antigen in pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disease that presents with intraepidermal blisters and a positive Nikolsky sign. Option B . Collagen 7: This is the target antigen in epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, another autoimmune blistering disease that presents with tense blisters and scarring. Option D. Laminin 332: This is the target antigen in junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic blistering disease that presents with skin and mucosal erosions from birth.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient with Tense blisters, vesicles and annular erythema comes to the OPD with itching in lesions. On examination, mucosal erosions were also observed. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Linear IgA disease Linear IgA disease bullous dermatosis belongs to the pemphigoid group of disorder. Adults= Linear IgA disease Childhood = Chronic bullous dermatosis of childhood (CBDC) Characteristic lesions: Blisters and vesicles frequently arise in an annular pattern with blistering along the edge of lesions forming the so‐called ‘string‐of‐pearls’ , ‘crown of jewels’ or ‘cluster of jewels’ sign . Linear IgA disease CBDC 6th decade 4 to 5 years old Localization occurs at a later stage of disease lesions arise abruptly, perioral area and perineum Mucosal involvement is common (in about 70 per cent of patients) with mostly oral erosions and ulcers; nasal crusting and genital lesions may also occur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: Tense bullae present with negative nikolsky sign Option C. Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita: Mechanical trauma-induced blisters with history of consanguinity Option D. Pemphigus group of disorder: Flaccid blisters with positive Nikolsky and bullae spread sign.

questions.text: Mucosa is never involved in which of the following disorder:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pemphigus foliaceus In pemphigus foliaceous flaccid bullae occur(so flaccid and superficial that intact blisters are not seen; instead scales and crusts are seen). Lesions are not widespread like in PV but in seborrheic distribution, including the face, scalp, and upper trunk. Mucosa is not involved (contrast to pemphigus vulgaris)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Oral lichen planus has oral mucosal lesions in the form of white reticulate patches and lacy lesions in mouth. Option C- SLE has oral palatal ulcers. Option D- TEN typically has mucosal involvement in the form of oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and eye involvement. The skin lesions are targetoid and tender. It is due to adverse drug reaction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient came to the OPD with rashes over her elbows and buttocks. The rashes are extremely itchy. She has no sign of atopy as such. No other complaints. The direct immunofluorescence of the lesion is shown below. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dermatitis herpetiformis The given clinical scenario with direct immunofluorescence finding showing a Granular or fibrillar pattern is of Dermatitis herpetiformis. Dermatitis herpetiformis, aka Duhring's disease, is a subepidermal immunobullous disease. Target antigen: Epidermal transglutaminase 3 Autoantibody: IgA Associated with Gluten-sensitive enteropathy Characteristics: Intensely pruritic papulovesicles over extensors and buttocks. Histopathology: Subepidermal split Papillary tip microabscess Direct immunofluorescence: Granular or fibrillar pattern Treatment: Gluten-free diet ( BROW = barley, rye, oats, wheat) DAPSONE

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Irritant contact dermatitis: It is a form of skin inflammation caused by contact with substances and environmental factors that injure the skin, damaging the skin barrier. Option B. Scabies infection: Scabies is a skin infection caused by the organism Sarcoptes Scabiei and is spread through close skin contact with affected individuals. It causes itchy, exudative lesions on the face, palms and soles. Option D . Eczema: aka atopic dermatitis, characterised by a dry, itchy rash, often with a history of asthma and hay fever.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to you with a history of blister formation on the body. On examination, the blisters are flaccid, clear fluid-filled, tend to burst and are without a tendency to heal. The lesions involve the scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back. Involvement of the oral mucosa in the form of ill-defined irregularly shaped erosions is present. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pemphigus Vulgaris The given clinical history of flaccid blisters with involvement of oral mucosa is suggestive of Pemphigus Vulgaris. It is an immunobullous disease ( Type 2 hypersensitivity, IgG antibodies ) which commonly presents at 40 to 60 years of age. Target protein: Desmosomes Target antigen: DSG3> DSG1 Characteristics: Flaccid bullae with positive bullae spread sign and nikolsky sign. 90 to 95% of patients have oral mucosal lesions. Histopathology: Acantholytic cells Suprabasal split Intact basal layer Direct immunofluorescence: Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 with a reticular pattern Treatment: High dose systemic steroids, cyclophosphamide, Rituximab

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A -Pemphigus Foliaceus: It involves the seborrheic areas of the body. There is no oral involvement. Flaccid vesicles are present, which tend to heal spontaneously. Option B -Paraneoplastic Pemphigus: It is characterised by Polymorphous mucocutaneous eruption(Intractable stomatitis, Conjunctivitis and bullous and erosive lesions elsewhere) Option D -Pemphigus Vegetans: It presents with Tumid, Vegetating hypertrophic plaques in the intertriginous areas. There is also the presence of a Cerebriform tongue.

questions.text: A mother brought her 18-month-old son for a routine check-up. On examination, the child was malnourished, weighing 10.9kg (25th percentile) and height of 83.9cm (75th percentile). The mother said the child had passed increasing watery, non-bloody stools several times daily since weaning started. A biopsy specimen from the small intestine demonstrates blunting of intestinal villi and lymphocytic infiltrate in lamina propria. Which of the following would most likely be seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Erythematous, grouped vesicular rash on extensors

questions.correct_answer: A. Erythematous, grouped vesicular rash on extensors
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erythematous, grouped vesicular rash on extensors The biopsy specimen from the small intestine demonstrates blunting of the intestinal villi and lymphocytic infiltration in the lamina propria is suggestive of celiac sprue -an autoimmune-mediated intolerance of gliadin (wheat). Celiac disease is associated with Dermatitis herpetiformis. It is characteristically an erythematous, vesicular rash similar to herpes. In some cases, dermatitis herpetiformis can also lead to T-cell lymphoma. Dermatitis herpetiformis, aka Duhring's disease, is a subepidermal immunobullous disease. Target antigen: Epidermal transglutaminase 3 Autoantibody: IgA Associated with Gluten-sensitive enteropathy Characteristics: Intensely pruritic papulovesicles over extensors and buttocks. Histopathology: Subepidermal split Papillary tip microabscess Direct immunofluorescence: Granular or fibrillar pattern Treatment: Gluten-free diet ( BROW = barley, rye, oats, wheat) DAPSONE

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Flaccid intraepidermal bullae: Seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris Option C. Fluid-filled, nonulcerating bullae: Seen in Bullous pemphigoid Option D. Nonpruritic scaly rash: Seen in psoriasis

questions.text: A 30-year-old male had severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year. Direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesions showed lgA deposition at dermoepidermal junction. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dermatitis herpetiformis Itchy papulovesicular lesions on elbows with IgA deposits at the DEJ is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH)

Highyeild:

DH is Extremely distressing and severely itchy disease characterized by grouped, symmetrical papulovesicles on extensor surfaces (e.g. elbow) Due to severe itch, intact blisters are rarely seen—excoriations (scratch marks) are more common 70–100% patients of DH have underlying coeliac disease (gluten-sensitive enteropathy Gluten (found in cereals except for rice and corn) flares the disease IgA antibodies against epidermal transglutaminase (TTG) which are present in the papillary tip are pathogenic Investigation: Circulating IgA antibodies against the smooth muscle cell endomysium (anti-endomysial antibodies) and IgA antibodies against TTG are present Histopathology—Neutrophils accumulate in the dermal papillae (papillary tip microabscess), subepidermal blister Treatment—Dapsone is the DOC (acts as a neutrophil remover from papilla) along with a gluten-free diet (to avoid wheat, barley, and rye).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- pemphigus vulgaris will have mucocutaneous ulceration without itching. It would show IgG deposits in the epidermis. Option B- Bullous pemphigoid will have tense itchy blisters on a red base in elderly. IgG deposits at DEJ Option D- Nummular eczema is also called as discoid eczema and has round scaly lesions without antibody deposits.

questions.text: In an 8-day-old child with history of consanguinity in the parents, the mother reports blisters and bleeding of the skin at the site of handling and pressure. There was a similar history in the previous child, which proved to be fatal. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital epidermolysis bullosa Congenital epidermolysis bullosa (EB) would be the diagnosis as the question mentions blisters at the site of handling the baby. Trauma induced disasters are seen in EB.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Bullous pemphigoid will have tense blisters in elderly. It has no relation to trauma induced history. Option B- congenital syphilis will have blisters but no relation to trauma Option D- Pemphigus is an acquired disease as an autoimmune blister.

questions.text: A 54 years old woman came to the physician because of painful blisters under her arms for 3 days and intermittent, painful lesions in her mouth. On examination, multiple flaccid bullae were seen in both armpits, and several erosions on the buccal mucosa and lips were noted. Skin biopsy showed detached keratinocytes within the stratum spinosum. This patient's condition is most likely caused by autoantibodies directed against components of which of the following cell junctions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Desmosomes The given clinical history is suggestive of Pemphigus Vulgaris. IgG autoantibodies to desmosomal components (desmoglein 1 and 3) can be seen in patients with pemphigus vulgaris. The formation of autoantibodies to these structural proteins results in loss of cell-cell adhesion, leading to mucocutaneous blister formation, as seen in this patient. It is an immunobullous disease ( Type 2 hypersensitivity, IgG antibodies ) which commonly presents at 40 to 60 years of age. Target protein: Desmosomes Target antigen: DSG3> DSG1 Characteristics: Flaccid bullae with positive bullae spread sign and nikolsky sign. -90 to 95% of patients have oral mucosal lesions. Histopathology: Acantholytic cells Suprabasal split Intact basal layer Direct immunofluorescence: Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 with a reticular pattern Treatment: High dose systemic steroids, cyclophosphamide, Rituximab

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Gap junctions: These are channels that allow for the direct communication and exchange of small molecules between adjacent cells. Autoantibodies directed against gap junctions have not been associated with any known autoimmune bullous disorder. Option B. Tight junctions: These are a type of cell junction that create a barrier between adjacent cells, regulating the movement of ions and molecules across cell layers. Autoantibodies directed against tight junctions have not been associated with any known autoimmune bullous disorder. Option C. Hemidesmosomes: These are specialized cell junctions that anchor epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane. Autoantibodies directed against hemidesmosomes are associated with a subtype of bullous but not with Pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: In congenital dystrophic epidermolysis, bullosa defect is seen in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Collagen type 7 Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa An inherited variant affecting the skin and other organs Butterfly children : Skin is seen to be as delicate and fragile as a butterfly's wings Caused by genetic defects (or mutations) within the human COL7 Al gene encoding the protein type VII collagen (collagen VII)

Extraedge:

Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) is a group of inherited diseases that are characterised by blistering lesions on the skin and mucous membranes. EB type site of blister formation Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) Epidermis or uppermost layer of skin cells (keratinocytes) Junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) Lamina lucida within the basement membrane zone Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB) Lamina densa and upper dermis

questions.text: A young boy with multiple flaccid bullous lesions over the trunk with oral mucosal lesions. Tzank finding is as shown below Most likely finding on biopsy would be?
questions.correct_answer: A. Fishnet IgG deposits in epidermis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fishnet IgG deposits in epidermis Multiple bullous lesions over the trunk with oral mucosa involvement hints towards and Tzanck showing a cell with hyperchromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo = Acantholysis, which is suggestive of Pemphigus vulgaris. It shows Fishnet IgG deposits in epidermis . It is an immunobullous disease ( Type 2 hypersensitivity, IgG antibodies ) which commonly presents at 40 to 60 years of age. Target protein: Desmosomes Target antigen: DSG3> DSG1 Characteristics: Flaccid bullae with positive bullae spread sign and nikolsky sign. 90 to 95% of patients have oral mucosal lesions. Histopathology: Acantholytic cells Suprabasal split: Row of tombstone appearance Intact basal layer Direct immunofluorescence: Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 with a reticular pattern Treatment: High dose systemic steroids, cyclophosphamide, Rituximab

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B .Linear IgG in Deposits: It is seen in bullous pemphigoid. Option C. Linear IgA in dermal papillae: It is seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis. Option D. Granular IgA in reticular dermis: It is seen in IgA pemphigus and linear IgA bullous dermatosis.
